The World Bank is poised to approve a groundbreaking USD 20 billion lending package for Pakistan under the "Pakistan Country Partnership Framework 2025-35." This long-term, 10-year initiative is designed to safeguard projects from political instability, focusing on six key areas: reducing child stunting, combating learning poverty, improving climate resilience, decarbonizing the environment, expanding fiscal space, and boosting private investment for productivity. These sectors enjoy broad political support and are expected to remain unaffected by government changes, ensuring consistency throughout the period, which will include multiple elections.

The package will consist of concessional loans from the International Development Association (IDA) totaling USD 14 billion, while the remaining USD 6 billion will be provided through the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). Additionally, the World Bank's private lending arms, the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), will contribute another USD 20 billion in private sector loans, bringing the total value to USD 40 billion.

This shift in strategy marks a move away from smaller, scattered investments to more substantial, targeted initiatives aimed at fostering long-term growth and stability. The framework will be finalized after approval on January 14, and the World Bank's Vice President for South Asia, Martin Raiser, is expected to visit Islamabad shortly afterward.

Indian Air Force (IAF) chief Air Chief Marshal (ACM) A.P. Singh on Tuesday (January 7, 2025) stressed that Research and Development (R&D) loses its relevance if it does not meet timelines, citing the prolonged delay in the indigenous Light Combat Aircraft (LCA) project. Conceived in 1984, the LCA project has still not delivered the first 40 aircraft by 2025, which has contributed to the IAF’s depleting fighter strength.

Speaking at the 21st Subroto Mukerjee seminar organised by the Centre for Air Power Studies, ACM Singh remarked, “Technology delayed is technology denied.” He called for a greater tolerance for risks and failures in R&D, emphasizing that setbacks are part of the process and should be treated as learning opportunities.

He further highlighted that self-reliance (Atma Nirbharta) in defence manufacturing “will come at a cost”, including higher prices and limited production runs. However, he argued that these challenges are necessary investments for achieving long-term technological and strategic autonomy for India.

Essential food items like meat and eggs remain expensive due to supply issues such as adverse weather. New government tariffs on imported goods, especially from China, are also contributing by raising production costs.

Although the Federal Reserve recently lowered its benchmark interest rate, inflation remains above its 2% target, potentially delaying further cuts.
